frameDefinitions: An Agent creates a Knot (possibly in a Place and/or with an Instrument).
A Wearer puts on an item of Clothing, which then occupies the Body_location.
An Agent matches location with an Entity in order to fulfill some  Purpose.
An Agent manipulates a Fastener to open or close a Containing_object (e.g. coat, jar).
This frame contains words that necessarily indicate the motion of two distinct objects.
A Visitor arrives at the Host_location as a guest of the Host, for the purpose of achieving a Purpose.
frameExamples: Loretta <t>ties</t> the most beautiful bowline I've ever seen.
You didn't have to <t>dress</t> like a pirate to impress me. INI
I ca n't remember how many times he <t>visited</t> ! DNI
Mary <t>closed</t> her coat with a belt.
She <t>accompanied</t> him in the ambulance to Hollywood Memorial Hospital.
I'm gonna <t>drop</t> <t>in</t> on Kieth for a while.
listRoleDefinitions: The Agent is the person performing the intentional act.
The stable configuration of a String which results from tying.
When the event occurs.
Where the event takes place.
The individual that puts <fen>Clothing</fen> on their body.
<fen>Clothing</fen> is used for the item of clothing that the <fen>Wearer</fen> ends up wearing.
The time when the <fen>Wearer</fen> puts an item of <fen>Clothing</fen> on.
The <fen>Place</fen> indicates where the Donning occurs.
The sentient entity that is temporarily with the <fen>Entity</fen> in order to fulfil some <fen>Purpose</fen>.

The physical entity that is permanently associated with entities or characteristics that the <fen>Agent</fen> wishes to use for some <fen>Purpose</fen>.  During the visit, the <fen>Agent</fen> matches location with the <fen>Entity</fen>.
The time at which a visit is made.
A description of the position of the <fen>Agent</fen> during the visit.

This role identifies the item that is closed by the agent with the fastener.
<fex name='Agent'>Lee</fex> <t>buttoned</t> <fex name='Containing_object'>his coat</fex>.
The Agent opens/closes the Containing-object.
This role identifies the fastener that the agent manipulates.
This role identifies the active zone of the container that may be expressed as the direct object of the target verb.
The time at which the <fen>Agent</fen> closes the <fen>Container_portal</fen> or the <fen>Containing_object</fen>.
The location where the closing event takes place.
This is the entity, frequently a living being, which moves in relation to the <fen>Cotheme</fen>. Normally the <fen>Theme</fen> frame element is expressed as an external argument.
This frame element is the second moving object, expressed as a direct object or an oblique:

<fen>Source</fen> marks any expression which implies a definite starting-point of the motion of the <fen>Cotheme</fen>. In prepositional phrases, the  object expresses the starting point of motion. With particles, the starting point of motion is understood from context.

<fen>Path</fen> marks phrases that describe the <fen>Theme</fen> and <fen>Cotheme</fen>'s trajectory of motion and which are neither expressions of the  <fen>Source</fen> nor the <fen>Goal</fen> of motion. The notion <fen>Path</fen> also includes directional expressions.

Any expression which tells where the <fen>Cotheme</fen> ends up as a result of the motion expresses the frame element <fen>Goal</fen>. Note that if the <fen>Cotheme</fen> is animate, the <fen>Theme</fen> need not also end up in the same place. Some particles imply the existence of a <fen>Goal</fen> which is understood in the context of utterance.

<fen>Area</fen> marks expressions which describe a general area in which the motion of <fen>Theme</fen> and <fen>Cotheme</fen> takes place when the motion is understood to be irregular and not to consist of a single linear path. Locative setting adjuncts of motion expressions may also be assigned this frame element.
Phrases that denote a physical path on which the motion of <fen>Theme</fen> and <fen>Cotheme</fen> takes place are marked <fen>Road</fen>.
The direction in which the <fen>Theme</fen> and <fen>Cotheme</fen> move.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the motion occurs.
The <fen>Place</fen> is the location which provides a setting for a defined motion (that is one with <fen>Source</fen>, <fen>Path</fen> or <fen>Goal</fen>).
The <fen>Visitor</fen> arrives at the Host_location to visit the <fen>Host</fen> for a <fen>Purpose</fen>.

The <fen>Host</fen> is the person highly associated with the goal location of the <fen>Visitor</fen>, and who allows the <fen>Visitor</fen> onto his/her territory, and possibly to make use of available resources. The <fen>Host</fen> and <fen>Visitor</fen> and in a host-guest relationship.
The <fen>Host_location</fen> is a place primarily associated with the <fen>Host</fen>.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when arriving occurs.
The larger area within which the visiting takes place.
listRoleExamples: She had put the dress on <fex>this morning</fex> expecting it to be sunny.
Marcus tied his shoe <fex>with the neon-green shoelaces</fex>.
They close the bank vault <fex>at precisely 5:35PM</fex>.
Shouldn't you have buttoned that <fex>in the bathroom</fex>?
<fex>Pat</fex> accompanied me for five miles in a blue Toyota.
The cat chased the mouse <fex>out of the house</fex>.
The children chased the ball <fex>into the park</fex>. (The children end up in the park.)
The police followed the suspects <fex>all around town</fex>.
The police followed the suspect <fex>on the interstate</fex> for several miles.
The tracking dogs chased their target <fex>towards the river</fex>, where they lost it.
